content: The federal K-12 education legislation, starting from the Improving America's Schools Act in 1994 to the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001, focused on granting flexibility to grantees. The NCLB expanded existing flexibility authorities and introduced new ones for state and local administration of federal K-12 education programs. This report outlines these authorizations and will be updated periodically to include significant developments. This report provides an overview of authorizations for state and local flexibility in administering federal K-12 education programs. It defines "flexibility" as the authority to waive federal program requirements for eligible state or local aid recipients. This flexibility may be granted in exchange for meeting accountability requirements related to program outcomes, including the consolidation of multiple programs. The flexibility granted for federal K-12 education programs includes provisions for consolidation of programs and transfer of funds, as well as the authority to waive program requirements. These authorities mainly apply to programs authorized by the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA).
